When I trained to be a lawyer (many years ago) it was impressed upon me that one of the obligations of a practising lawyer was to do some pro bono work as a matter of course.

Now this was in a conservative jurisdiction. It was also one that had a state funded Legal Aid System. Notwithstanding, we were told that professional training and privilege had a price, and part of that price was the performance of pro bono work. As a matter of course. Without being asked.

So my sister (and brother) litigators, it is time to step forward.

I no longer practice, but if I did, I know where I'd be.

Before the Silk Road closed, people searching for heroin and other drugs had a mostly reliable marketplace for buying largely safe product from reviewed dealers. It was a sensible system for people who wanted to buy drugs-- get substances that at least weren't adulterated with dangerous fillers. And you get to buy the stuff from people who could, mostly, be trusted.

When will the US government learn? When will we learn?

If we legalize drugs and create an excellent educational foundation that properly instructs the youth about these drugs, and if we create an effective system of treatment--rather than punishment-- for the misuse (not just occasional use) of these substances, then we'd have a far better and stronger country. Instead, we have a country that says "Drugs are bad" and then when we experiment with these "bad drugs" and do so without any formal or wise advice, we abuse them, often, which makes sense, since our abstinence-only drug problem is doomed to fail.

Heroin is not intrinsically bad, nor are any drugs. The problem is misuse. If we can educate our youth, properly treat our addicts, and create a culture of understanding rather than one of condemnation, we'll be well on our way to making a better America.

Another consideration favoring "Demonstration" projects is to use them in the role of Phase I clinical trials, where treatment protocols are tried, evaluated and adjusted to create a situation where Phase II and III Clinical Trials may be conducted because the Phase I trials demonstrated safety and established a protocol.

The obvious difficulty with both Phase I clinical trials and "Demonstration Projects" is the temptation to leap to unsupported conclusions about the results without further validation.

There are procedural demonstrations which have dramatically improved outcomes when adopted. An example is the "Time Out" protocol at the beginning of a surgical procedure.

Before I had rotator cuff surgery several years ago, I used washable marker to indicate which shoulder to treat. The doctor was somewhat put off by my marks, one of which--on the other shoulder--said "NOT HERE, DUMMY!" Since the adoption of "Time Out", I no longer feel such a need.

The problem is not that we cannot observe people in the status quo state. The problem is that we cannot observe people that we know are comparable to the recipients of a given program. We can observe changes in the treatment group, but we cannot know how much of that change to attribute to the program without some sort of counterfactual. People who didn't get the program are often quite different from the people who did get it, even if they look similar on paper. There are, after all, reasons that certain people seek out such programs and others do not; some of those reasons lead to selection biases.

There are indeed credible methods for evaluation other than randomized trials, but they are rarely as compelling as an RCT.

"Research, among others, has upended a key assumption of the Affordable Care Act. It was thought that insured people would save the nation money because they would use emergency rooms less, but it has turned out that they have used them more."

And this "upending" has been soundly and roundly criticized as a premature conclusion drawn in a study with an insufficient time scale, at the least. It takes time for a population to get plugged in to the health care network - finding a primary care physician, for example, as a first step. Until the integration occurs, the emergency rooms will continue to be (over)used.

Similarly, comparing these trials to drug trials is specious. The "placebo controlled, double blind" experiment is under increasing fire on ethical grounds: it is not OK to deny care to a placebo group when an positive effect is found, just to satisfy a protocol or to improve statistics. Further, it is hotly debated whether a "placebo" is an ethically appropriate standard - why isn't a proven drug set as a standard? This has substantial bearing on pharmaceutical costs in the US, where proprietary, patented drugs are touted as the latest and greatest, while offering small, if any, advantages over older, off-patent drugs.

@ LMC-

I don't see any ethical slippery slope at all, as long as these decisions are made by the individual couple-- not by "society". The parents are the ones who are going to have to raise the child, and watch them suffer if they develop various medical conditions. They're the ones who are going to have to provide lifetime, 24/7 care, if the child is severely disabled enough to require it. They should absolutely have the right to use this type of screening for any issue they choose.

I'd like to think we're well past the days when hospitals and other institutions made the unilateral decision to sterilize people, take their children away without cause, etc. There is large body of constitutional and human rights law around the world to prevent these sorts of abuses from happening again. I don't think it's realistic that we would see that again in the US.

Human eggs and sperm are human and alive, but we don't tell young people to produce as many pregnancies as possible to keep their eggs and sperm from dying. A fertilized egg is a complete program for a human life, but it is not yet a person. To knowingly allow a real person to experience pain and suffering, just to avoid discarding an embryo, is absurd,

The death of a parent can cause lifelong emotional problems and depression, and thinking about other orphans in the world doesn't magically make that go away. Those kids don't feel "lucky", and it's rather insulting to insist that they should.

I feel lucky to have seen Mr. Hoffman in several plays in New York but I will never forget his performance in A Long Day's Journey Into Night.   In fact after seeing that show I was standing in front of the theater waiting for my friends to make their way out. Everyone was doing what you do after a show, bumping their way out when I realized I was face to face with Mr. Hoffman, who was quietly making his way through the crowd.  I broke my rule about leaving actors to their privacy and just blurted out what was in my head, "you were magnificent" He smiled generously and thanked me. I hope at some level he knew what a great actor he was. There will never be another like him.
